Award.AwardTitle: Linking Electronic Structure with Continuum Fields: Coarse-Graining Density Functional Theory

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate the fundamental impact of crystal defects on material behavior through quantum-mechanical Density Functional Theory calculations. In particular, a seamless multiscale method that will enable the accurate study of defects at realistic concentrations is proposed. This method will be developed in the framework of a novel linear-scaling technique for Density Functional Theory, which traditionally has a cubic-scaling with respect to the number of atoms. Additionally, numerical coarse-graining approximations tailored to the nature of the defect will be utilized. The optimality of the overall formulation will be ensured through rigorous mathematical analysis. As an application, the proposed multiscale method will be used to study the effect of alloying on the strength and ductility of Magnesium with the goal of discovering novel alloys. Also, constitutive laws will be generated for dislocation dynamics simulations and, using these, the size-dependent strength observed during compression of nanopillars will be investigated.

If successful, the project will provide a breakthrough in bridging the electronic structure and continuum descriptions of crystal defects. This will significantly advance the current understanding of deformation and failure mechanisms in solids. Consequently, it will accelerate the discovery of novel materials with properties tailored to technological applications. As an example, new magnesium alloys with improved specific strength will have a noticeable impact on the transportation industry where there is a need for weight reduction without compromising structural integrity. Such alloys will help reduce fuel consumption, thereby also having a positive influence on the environment. The educational efforts of the project include broad dissemination of research results through social media and academic curriculum, creating a new website that documents the state of the art in crystal defect calculations, organizing conference symposia, and training graduate, undergraduate and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Simulations based on quantum-mechanics are commonplace in nearly all fields of science and engineering. In particular, quantum-mechanical calculations can be used to accurately determine the electronic, chemical, mechanical, optical, and thermal properties of materials systems from first principles, i.e., without any apriori assumptions regarding their behavior. However, such ab-initio calculations are associated with tremendous computational expense, which severely restricts the size of systems that can be studied. This motivates the development of methods that enable the quantum-mechanical study of systems at larger length and time scales, which has been successfully achieved in this project as follows:

  • A new methodology and software referred to as SPARC (Simulation Package for Ab-initio Real-space Calculations) for performing quantum-mechanical calculations has been developed. SPARC is able to study nanostructures as well bulk materials. Notably, SPARC is able to outperform previous well-established and optimized Density Functional Theory (DFT) codes by up to an order of magnitude, thereby enabling the ab-initio study of systems of significantly larger size.
  • A new methodology and software referred to as SQDFT (Spectral Quadrature DFT) has been developed that overcomes the cubic-scaling bottleneck faced by traditional DFT formulations and implementations.  In particular, the linear scaling SQDFT is able to efficiently utilize supercomputers consisting of hundreds of thousands of cores, thereby outperforming previous well-established DFT codes by up to two orders of magnitude, especially for high temperature calculations. 
  • A new methodology and software referred to as RS-FD (Real-space Finite-Differences) has been developed for performing large-scale Orbital-Free DFT calculations. RS-FD is able to efficiently utilize powerful supercomputers, thereby enabling quantum-mechanical simulations of significantly larger size than previously feasible.
  • A new efficient and robust iterative method for solving linear systems of equations has been developed, which is referred to as AAR (Alternating Anderson-Richardson).  In particular, AAR is able to outperform state of the art linear solvers by up to an order of magnitude.
  • A new extrapolation technique for accelerating the convergence of fixed-point iterations (commonly used approaches for solving linear and nonlinear systems of equations) has been developed.  In particular, the developed technique is able to outperform currently existing state of the art techniques by factors of two to three.
  • A new method for predicting the nucleation of defects in large-scale atomistic calculations has been developed. This approach has been utilized to enhance our understanding of the mechanisms involved in nucleation of a dislocation (commonly encountered crystal defect that governs plastic behavior of materials).

Overall, the developed computational methods and software for studying the mechanical, electrical and chemical properties of materials systems is expected to become an important tool in a variety of disciplines including solid mechanics, materials science, physics, chemistry and nanotechnology.

The educational efforts of the project include the following:

  • Inter-disciplinary training for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students at the intersection of mechanics, mathematics, materials science and physics.
  • Organization of multiple inter-disciplinary symposiums at important research conferences.
  • Development of a new course on solid mechanics for the graduate curriculum.
  • Broad dissemination of the results through social media.
